TopicTitle: CLASS E Asteroid on an Encounter Trajectory with Kerbin!!!!!! Help!

Articles.Content:
Okay, I got tons of asteroids orbiting the sun most small or medium, But there's ONE Class E on an encounter trajectory with kerbin, What do i do? It's orbiting the sun at the moment but it's current orbit is leading to a kerbin encounter trajectory, How do i stop this?

(my first ever asteroid i've done the scenario which was fun but now i'm on my own)

So should i send sattellites then a ship to go grab it or what? Please walk me through this steps please hehe.

"Encounter" or "impact"?

Seriously, you don't have to sweat roids. They won't hurt anything if they hit Kerbin.

Size E roids weigh like 3000 tons so they take SERIOUS horsepower to move them at all. You might want to start with something smaller.

There's already a thread on how to rendezvous with roids:

http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/74559-How-to-rendez-vous-with-an-asteroid

In general, though, the point is to change the roid from being a fly-by (or impact) to being in a stable orbit somewhere in the Kerbin system, so you can then study it at leisure. Or make the thing crash into KSC or your Mun base. Whatever mood you're in .

An E class was actually the first thing I captured =P

If it's the same one that I got you can do it a bunch of nervas and 2 orange tanks. I would recommend at least 6 nervas. This will get you about 150 m/s.

It will require about 50 m/s once you grabbed it. 30 to get it on a gracing encounter with kerbin, and then just a few meters per second to capture it. You will need quite a bit of RCS aswell.

Also wrestling with that enormous thing I found that the easiest way to deal with them is to unlock the pivot of the claw and then try to keep pushing the center of mass towards the maneuver marker, like you would push the retrograde marker towards your target in the final stages of a rendezvous. If you attempt to do it with the pivot locked any misalignment will produce some amount of torque, and when you notice it there will be so much momentum that it's very hard to stop.
